snippet: Radical Sunni militants freed prisoners, set fire to police stations and seized mosques in Falluja and Ramadi, two of Iraq’s most important cities.
abstract: Radical Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda threaten to seize control of Falluja and Ramadi, setting fire to police stations, freeing prisoners from jail and occupying mosques; government forces rush reinforcement troops to the two key cities, both centers of Sunni extremism since Americans withdrew in 2011; violence has implications beyond Iraq, as militants are fighting under same banner as the most hard-line jihadists they have inspired in Syria.

byline.original: By YASIR GHAZI and TIM ARANGO
byline.contributor: Yasir Ghazi reported from Baghdad, and Tim Arango from Istanbul. An employee of The New York Times contributed reporting from Falluja, Iraq, and Michael R. Gordon from Jerusalem.

lead_paragraph: Radical Sunni militants freed prisoners, set fire to police stations and seized mosques in Falluja and Ramadi, two of Iraq’s most important cities.

headline.main: Qaeda-Aligned Militants Threaten Key Iraqi Cities
headline.print_headline: Qaeda-Aligned Militants Threaten Key Iraqi Cities
